title: Secondary – Cycle 2 – Progression of Learning - Ethics and Religious Culture (2011)
subject: Personal Development

document.title: Secondary – Cycle 2 – Progression of Learning - Ethics and Religious Culture (2011)

3AE011B0AE6041CD99FC440AB72C69C2.description: a conspiracy (e.g. “Can you prove that the politicians agreed on this point?”)

3514542404CB46EDA33572365289708C.description: a slippery slope (e.g. “Aren’t you exaggerating a little? Being late for this class will not determine the rest of my life.”)

10586F7A4C7A4232B6EA4A3D9DF1DDE5.description: a false analogy (e.g. “Are the same skills required to sing and to play the guitar?”)

B6A852E395344F67A8022B040439EBC2.description: a causal fallacy (e.g. “Do all players who score goals use sticks autographed by their idols?”)

6D23542F92ED4789872EAA58E09DAB25.description: a false dilemma (e.g. “What is the connection between getting your driver’s license and doing housework?”)

7C31F626CFB740EF823614593D8CD47C.description: a straw man argument (e.g. “What would we do in the middle of winter?”)

3970D123A9824D678352D3E0D6E84D19.description: “two wrongs don’t make a right” argument (e.g. “If your friend goes home at 7:00 p.m., should you do likewise?”)

8006A49E936A4C23A5061897D84726AC.description: an argument from authority (e.g. “Regardless of what the sociologist said and regardless of his reputation, what do you think and what are your arguments?”)

D9A164867CF64E24B9D92A4D924EBE25.description: an appeal to stereotype (e.g. “What is your basis for saying that boys are less co-dependent than girls?”)

21342F8FD5854109ABDF0C26D835F286.description: an appeal to prejudice (e.g. “Can you give me your definition of autonomy?”)

E4B4711B7A3F4E3597482B78EE67E405.description: an appeal to the people (e.g. “Does the number of computers sold guarantee the quality of the model?”)

51065404779B4185BC99C75CE9B871B0.description: an appeal to the crowd (e.g. “Is everything your friends say always true?”)

CEC59450D55B4FA0AF8D274891750E7D.description: a personal attack (e.g. “Do you really think that insulting me will help us find the solution?”)

BCCE1F0F9486478EA8BCCB841BE471EA.description: a hasty generalization (e.g. “What is your basis for saying that all adolescents disobey their parents?”)

D9360237197840C3849E0C3511EF7201.description: Questions, in a situation involving dialogue:

C8ABE8847BC1478D89740F4121AE1D8A.description: a conspiracy (e.g. “We will never be able to save the planet because politicians in all the rich countries have agreed that the economy is their priority.”)

49EFF3455994476D87F5CB3BF7427C3B.description: a slippery slope (e.g. “If you are late for class one more time, you will fail your exam, you won’t get your high school diploma and you will never find a job.”)

506DCC0CEC684DA69E30FE188BEB5B85.description: a false analogy (e.g. “Since that student plays the guitar so well, he or she must sing well.”)

A26D8AE441214AC68325E0F6BFD9F216.description: a causal fallacy (e.g. “I scored a goal because I was playing with a hockey stick signed by my idol.”)

1BA45D27D0D84FD7999ACB33317F66D5.description: a false dilemma (e.g. “Either you let me get my driver’s license or I won’t do any more housework.”)

886F09DC9D60427D9116870B32CA9566.description: a straw man argument (e.g. “Ecologists think that we should all wear green plants in order to save the planet.”)

B563415CF66A4F38B1A7E1B0F8283AB0.description: “two wrongs don’t make a right” argument (e.g. “You came home much too late last night.” “But Dad, my friend Sam went home two hours later than I did!”)

61526A3AF350450997B457F2825C0CD7.description: an argument from authority (e.g. “I believe there is life after death because a famous sociologist said so.”)

901C464B1674407DBD4ECFD44359E06E.description: an appeal to stereotype (e.g. “Boys are less co-dependent than girls.”)

9D1EF4DF0F5A453C88B8E0AC8006E6EC.description: an appeal to prejudice (e.g. “A handicapped person can never be autonomous.”)

322696DDFF444F61BC61289FCD968E23.description: an appeal to the crowd (e.g. “This computer has the highest sales; that means it must be the best model.”)

07DE29B9AA8448B09B61B479A4D51FC9.description: an appeal to the people (e.g. “My friends all say that the best form of justice is fairness, so it must be true.”)

1CAF9E9500E94690A1DC031383FE3E36.description: a personal attack (e.g. “You are not smart enough to find the solution.”)

F5C52DCF0A5544669A791DB6A5EAC814.description: a hasty generalization (e.g. “All adolescents disobey their parents.”)

8E87DB90AFFA47D19A17CDA3FF153151.description: Recognizes, in a situation involving dialogue:

5F2E24822445403EB2184E700DBBAA43.description: “two wrongs don’t make a right” argument, a straw man argument, a false dilemma, a causal fallacy, a false analogy, a slippery slope, a conspiracy

6AD06D857C6C46F19A5DE04B2BF701CB.description: a hasty generalization, a personal attack, an appeal to the people, an appeal to the crowd (bandwagon), an appeal to prejudice, an appeal to stereotype, an argument from authority

36A0C68C50E54C5B82F08026A8F6CB09.description: a judgment of value (e.g. “How is the social order more important to you than freedom?”)

FC01FD31A3FC46FAB06E8D1765769EE3.description: a judgment of reality (e.g. “Can you give an example of a story that has inspired the creation of a rite?”)

66677AAA7ABF470C8D38332595EFE79B.description: a judgment of prescription (e.g. “Do I have to respect someone else’s freedom even if it limits my freedom?”)

0D9B5B90F8074739AE335A689CF99609.description: a judgment of preference (e.g. “How are your parents’ norms better than those imposed by your friends’ parents?”)

FDDA903CCBF14CE891108B0F208B7CEE.description: Questions, in a situation involving dialogue:

7344CFF87F484E3394E26E2FB9D7E235.description: a judgment of value (e.g. “The social order is more important than freedom.”)

31CEE07CBC6C4B8EB57507FF831F133D.description: a judgment of reality (e.g. “The Bible tells a number of stories that have inspired the creation of religious rites.”)

645049C24BC9447880A1917F3C073096.description: a judgment of prescription (e.g. “It’s important to respect the freedom of others.”)

2EA2900DEF93423E9DFB541B6BBE44F2.description: a judgment of preference (e.g. “I prefer the norms imposed by my parents to those imposed by my friends’ parents.”)

8ACCE1E07EC043888F63598FEE254DC3.description: Recognizes, in a situation involving dialogue:

EFFBD98810D34012AEDC876E0F0AAB71.description: Explains, in his/her own words the meaning of a judgment of preference, a judgment of prescription, a judgment of reality and a judgment of value

840DA5F7955F487393BBD1252BDB391F.description: Means for examining a point of view

49D931E541434949806415ECAD4EECA1.description: reasoning by hypothesis (e.g. “Can a scientific study confirm this hypothesis?”)

6391F98C06DC40A48A595F64B8D8AB7E.description: reasoning by analogy (e.g. “Can you name some big differences between riding a bike and driving a scooter?”)

1F51182EAA50453F9B53F39EC959C2FB.description: reasoning by deduction (e.g. “Is it possible for someone who practises a team sport to be in poor physical shape?”)

2EC95171C27343F48EB0D6A33B68D14A.description: reasoning by induction (e.g. “How can we say that what is true for one person is true for everyone?”)

DDA7079D7A5F459A947BB0A7905BD865.description: Questions, in a situation involving dialogue:

3AAF58DDC7B341DC909BADEFA28E69F7.description: reasoning by hypothesis (e.g. “People who do 30 minutes or more of physical activity a day have a longer life expectancy than the national average.”)

93A18366A2914A19A327A85A4CAE6C6B.description: reasoning by analogy (e.g. “I can ride my bike safely, following road safety rules. Therefore, I can drive a scooter.”)

789272572B39474C823C450228D4048F.description: reasoning by deduction (e.g. “Team sports require members to be in good physical shape. Therefore, anyone who practises team sports must be in good physical shape.”)

C02A68C715F04C53AC05B2CA9DE03BFE.description: reasoning by induction (e.g. “My friend Marie listens to music while she studies and she does very well. Therefore, listening to music must foster success.”)

44827E1348A04731ADED3E37F0F01929.description: Recognizes, in a situation involving dialogue:

1D59EE3D494C41E590154B706B44EAB6.description: Explains in his/her own words: reasoning by induction, deduction, analogy, hypothesis

3179CD7ECB2142E093BCA264898144B2.description: Uses justification to present, in a logical way, a few reasons and ideas that support a point of view (e.g. in Cycle One, “I think everyone’s freedom is limited because there are rules, codes of conduct and laws that govern our behaviour;” in Cycle Two, “I believe that a pilgrimage is a religious experience, because the believer finds a spiritual meaning there and becomes personally involved, which strengthens his or her faith.”)

A2B8C75FFBDD4F1DB3175EBA88A38C77.description: Uses explanation to help others to know or understand the meaning of the subject discussed (e.g. in Cycle One, social order is an agreement between the members of a group about norms to be respected and values to be espoused; in Cycle Two, human ambivalence is a state in which a person is undecided about two options as they both involve equally important values)

5453FF0664C0445CA7028737847EA971.description: Uses synthesis to provide a coherent summary of the elements of the subject discussed (e.g. in Cycle One, summarizes what he/she has learned about connections between the stories, rites and rules of religious traditions; in Cycle Two, summarizes his/her understanding of the different answers religious traditions propose for an existential question)

00DF51AED35C4A0387E4016EE7D6E026.description: Uses comparison to highlight similarities and differences among the elements of the subject discussed (e.g. in Cycle One, names two differences between an adolescent and an adult’s conception of freedom; in Cycle Two, indicates the similarities and differences between Hubert Reeves and David Suzuki’s vision of the future of humanity)

037FE2BE5CA14E1B866A9F15944E40BA.description: Uses description to enumerate the characteristics of the subject discussed (e.g. in Cycle One, in the context of a story, describes the setting where the action takes place, the characters and the important events; in Cycle Two, in the context of a religious experience, describes the place where the experience took place, what the person felt, what actions were taken, what words were spoken, etc.)

6C579D69F659447FB3AFC28E87A2C1E8.description: Explains, in his/her own words, the use of description, comparison, synthesis, explanation and justification

95FFB37E135F48A4A310C1785224AF4F.description: Means for developing a point of view

A10851240C644AB2B786340F89610549.description: considers all other paths for fostering dialogue

C793106AA2E9436CBD016E14A16A65B7.description: is open to different ways of thinking

D1CF82FBF9754849A464F8709D1B6DBE.description: introduces nuances to his/her comments and recognizes the nuances introduced by others

CEF0A7B033C94277B522C6768C067399.description: suggests rules for engaging in dialogue

F9030859D528487494863E22BC46D2FF.description: Contributes to establishing conditions that foster dialogue:

8871096A2BF24B2785D3815E3E9507F2.description: considers all other paths for fostering dialogue,

086A73BED47B4BE6B43F2C2145E1577C.description: attentively listens to what another person has to say in order to grasp the meaning

DAA3D3E16A2B44EEB82780EB0E44710B.description: respects the right of others to speak

3EE5E3DE8C814463BFBAAB8FDFA6A0D2.description: observes rules for engaging in dialogue

CE06DEA3C9794B7D9B8556774AB7B8CD.description: conversation, discussion, narration, deliberation, interview, debate

A1D80F9EFE234753A6AD06556E2FF667.description: Uses, in a situation involving dialogue

F16582E50260499C9C3CA8785F6FD87D.description: Explains, in his/her own words, the meaning of a panel

152570D3963D492283D89C78D9F6EB6A.description: Knowledge related to the pratice of dialogue: Competency 3 – Engages in dialogue

7299148B47A74CCDA9B0C709CB246A8B.description: Makes connections between the theme Religious references in art and culture and the recognition of others

BF0DF67FC3DA40B2BA30CB3C1B0C18E6.description: Makes connections between the theme Religious references in art and culture and the pursuit of the common good

AB4AD25A26974D5996A7EEDA0816DB0A.description: Makes connections between the theme Religious references in art and culture and the themes Religions down through time, Existential questions or Religious experience

71D825596CD9442DAD144F1E2FAD7477.description: Associates a work of art with the appropriate religious tradition (e.g. stained glass with Catholicism or Protestantism, an icon with the Orthodox tradition, a dance with Native spirituality, the image of a lotus flower with Hinduism or Buddhism)

248711E57FD9406B9A269DBA7DFCCE10.description: Explains the symbolism of certain religious references in works of art (e.g. the cross represents the death and resurrection of Jesus and, for believers, the salvation of God; the dove symbolizes peace in many Christian traditions; the eight-spoked Wheel of Dharma symbolizes the Noble Eightfold Path to enlightenment in Buddhism)

58C34509B6644EB99C2467A44C697E7F.description: Makes connections between what is represented in a work of art and a religious story (e.g. it is possible to make a connection between a picture of Moses crossing the Red Sea and the story of the Exodus in the Bible; Giuseppe Verdi’s opera Nabucco evokes the biblical story of the enslavement of Jews in Babylon)

22261155405744A49D7CD3F256714C25.description: Identifies, in works of art, characters, objects or a scene that contains a religious reference (e.g. a painting of the angel Gabriel; a sculpture that includes a crucifix; a film about the Exodus of the Israelites from Egypt)

0B70334F80ED47A8B965E223F38E8AE7.description: Describes works of art that contain a religious reference: type of work, author, intended audience, context in which it was created, role, etc

0431F7BAE33346EABD3275BA566849C6.description: Names works of art present in the social and cultural environment that contain religious references (e.g. picture, sculpture, object, theatre, film, place of worship)

4EDE038CAA5C4B499742A73B7BE200F4.description: Defines terms that could be linked to religious references in the arts and in culture (e.g. work of art, religious reference, culture, symbol, secular)

225E4DDA9AE5446C807C4F16D3304872.description: Religious references in art and culture

EB4C588D010340D3B5D54AFCFF95EE19.description: Makes connections between the theme Religious experience and the recognition of others

9E5A1E5EF91B4BFC91FB93380442D7A5.description: Makes connections between the theme Religious experience and the pursuit of the common good

15AAD7A8723A40C585FFCDBED8BD18ED.description: Makes connections between the theme Religious experience and the themes Religions down through time or Existential questions or Religious references in art and culture

32C6DD8CD40B46F29FC5DE9AABAA82A4.description: Associates a religious experience with the corresponding religious tradition (e.g. reciting the rosary with Catholicism, a pilgrimage to Mecca with Islam, the sweat lodge with Native spirituality)

5882A39CE49B45858963A470E973D94E.description: Describes the effects of religious experience: on a person (e.g. transformation, liberation, healing), on a community (e.g. sharing, involvement), on ways of life (e.g. asceticism, life as a hermit, monastic life, etc.)

DF402C30A5A9483985ECE4C260FDA383.description: Explains the meaning attributed to different exceptional religious experiences (e.g. conversion as a radical change for a believer)

50EF3348E8C14616A68A7828576C177E.description: Explains the meaning attributed to different daily religious experiences (e.g. prayer is a means of making personal and intimate contact with the divine)

5419751090604DE7942DE7A619E857F3.description: Describes religious experiences: sites, actions taken, objects used, people present, words spoken, feelings and emotions experienced, etc.

386E68D2263A420E803B9E3E1AA7298B.description: Names types of exceptional religious experience (e.g. conversion, ecstasy, illumination, pilgrimage)

AAD0D44425714D4EB8BD1C167BAD0295.description: Names types of religious experience in daily life (e.g. prayer, contemplation, admiring nature)

169CF9826791434CB22EA5692CC5751C.description: Makes connections between the theme Existential questions and the recognition of others

A6026B76320A424594EE4506D6741C62.description: Makes connections between the theme Existential questions and the pursuit of the common good

1CD1885F03E14920898D109626A87440.description: Makes connections between the theme Existential questions and the themes Religions down through time, Religious experience or Religious references in art and culture

16D1562274684C428614971318697A70.description: the constitution of human beings: soul, body spirit, permanence and impermanence of human beings, etc

EED4EE37B28F49249D49B7C2D00FB621.description: men and women: complementarity, sexuality, dignity, etc.

CE16CB02229C4E04ABC6CB57A0AD93B2.description: human origins: divine creature, natural being, natural evolution, etc.

AF229C7CC00F49D1A6BE88E082B349E4.description: Explains answers that various religious traditions or currents of thought have offered regarding the nature of human beings

796D8340BB6B483BA5A7B4322EB34029.description: human freedom: free will, predestination, fatalism, etc.

6A51DB69B8F8482A832A13DFA97464C1.description: life after death: resurrection, reincarnation, paradise, hell, nirvana, nothingness, etc

AC94F5E400954F599AB2F72D78103B8E.description: the human condition: birth, suffering, death, etc

69CFA59EF4DA4A7AAA9F74198CBB72A5.description: Explains answers that various religious traditions or currents of thought have offered regarding the meaning of life and death

7DBAFF32627C4B38AC5FC0985A29C986.description: critiques and denunciations: atheism, the idea of religious alienation, the idea of the death of God, etc.

54488146606A4E2D9CA2796B1BCE5E33.description: different doctrines: monotheism, polytheism, animism, pantheism, etc.

9E58427C60344595A878BC0E30698BE0.description: ways to affirm its existence: through nature, reason, feelings, experience, etc.

951D7B29DBAE489DA5D76FE876483AD2.description: Explains answers that various religious traditions or currents of thought have offered regarding the existence of the divine

AB532055D5C14FDD964F6E2688278E68.description: Makes connections between the theme Religions down through time and the recognition of others

4ACDE8D64F584099BE2EBF5107C9BFBA.description: Makes connections between the theme Religions down through time and the pursuit of the common good

DF24B4D295074C76B5D5617737F7F0BB.description: Makes connections between the theme Religions down through time and the themes Existential questions, Religious experience or Religious references in art and culture

5BB82EE2E0EA4780847BCF0077456402.description: Describes new religious movements: origins, characteristics

0D8E7A80CBF84FDCBE1B2B6DBE148481.description: Describes periods of religious renewal in different religious traditions: origins, characteristics

C1F1D0DBBE214319AA66A7CEFA195ACE.description: Describes the development and diffusion of certain religious traditions consolidation: institutions, councils, establishment of rules and dogma, trends and currents within various traditions: schisms, the Reformation and the Counter Reformation, relationships between religious and political powers, roles of men and women tensions, conflicts, reconciliations and reconnections, etc.

5D6E7C96D9114AF795102C374D5017CD.description: Describes the origins of certain religious traditions: religious affiliations, founding events (role and meaning), key figures, important places, important times, writings doctrines, etc

D658E53BA9164264B77AF750B7DC2AD0.description: Describes attributes of mythical or supernatural beings according to different cultures and religious traditions: physical characteristics, feelings, qualities, etc.

AFFD7B17E79E4759AB95DB4974E18F36.description: Names mythical and supernatural beings associated with different cultures and religious traditions (e.g. gods and goddesses, mythical animals, angels, devils, spirits)

56BF0FCD7BAB4C66B0662C6F6A33F906.description: Names symbols associated with the divine: colours: white, orange elements: fire, water vegetation: lotus flower, olive branch, etc.

C00C978581BB4DD18340E44FC7AEAC86.description: Describes attributes of the divine according to different traditions: qualifiers: good, merciful, creator, omnipresent, omnipotent physical characteristics: human form, animal form (Native spirituality), blue skin and many arms (Hinduism), etc.

3E3428BA717E4794948E90388B133C70.description: Gives the name or names attributed to the divine in different religious traditions: Christianity: Trinity, Father, Son, Holy Spirit Judaism: Adonai, Lord Native spirituality: Great Spirit Islam: Allah, etc

9698955CB1534B0DBC93698B89E490AC.description: Defines terms that can be related to the divine and to mythical or supernatural beings (e.g. divinity, mythology, goddess, demon, supernatural, spirit, angel)

A34F281171FB47FF9045F92DD53362F9.description: Representations of the divine and of mythical and supernatural beings

1F923DCF605C4B509EA7E7AA548634CF.description: Makes connections between the stories, rites and rules of a religious tradition (e.g. the celebration of the Eucharist [rite] originates from the passion of Jesus [story] and the Catholic church asks its followers to attend Sunday mass [rule]; the Jewish holiday Sukkot [rite] originates from the story of the exodus from Egypt and, for this holiday, Jews must build an outdoor dwelling [rule] and have a meal there)

F408225949924F53BB176671D6B13CCF.description: Makes connections between key elements of religious traditions and forms of religious expression in the environment (e.g. church bells [form of religious expression] announce Sunday services [rite])

2F9C9099108043F596D2A869885E92CF.description: Describes different rules in religious traditions: type of rule, origin, prohibitions, obligations, etc.

2E8113FBF4524CD9807DAEB614DFEA38.description: Describes different rites in religious traditions: type of rite, origin, characteristics, role, procedure, etc.

C0534BD3BD3D4B05811CB8EC51DE21B2.description: Describes different stories in religious traditions: type of story, origin, characteristics, role, etc

060A8C011C44471498381F21BA295D6E.description: Describes the influence of religious traditions on the folklore and works of art in Québec’s heritage (e.g. influence of Christianity in Québec literature)

5DF46E4A57F047F19DDC7C35EB44283D.description: Describes the influence of religious traditions on the values and norms in Québec society (e.g. influence on moral behaviour and moral codes, habits and customs, prohibitions)

DA0E95F0CBA14EA688C2A6DFAA9B58FE.description: Describes the contribution of religious institutions to Québec society, particularly in health care and education (e.g. construction of schools and hospitals, personnel mainly composed of nuns and monks, establishment of programs of study)

585BC465F79641438DAA1FD92B780E20.description: Describes religious institutions that are part of Québec’s heritage: origin, purpose, roles and responsibilities of religious personnel, hierarchy, etc.

AA438CA8F47A49A89030EFC9273E0A98.description: Names religious institutions that are part of Québec’s heritage (e.g. Frères du Sacré-Cœur community, the Sœurs de la Charité community)

10CB499147094C368F2DEF034D382FE7.description: Associates elements of religious heritage in the environment with founders (e.g. Hôtel-Dieu Hospital and the Augustinian nuns, the Society of Saint Vincent de Paul and the Vincentians)

980AB031E9FC470AB1E1646FF8E95B05.description: Names founders or influential figures in Québec’s religious heritage (e.g. Marie Guyart, Mgr François de Laval, Gaspar Soiaga Kondiaronk, Henriette Odin-Feller)

80967F0584D54A09B1D76DB913513A91.description: Defines terms that can be connected to religious heritage (e.g. heritage, religious heritage, institutions, folklore)

F4E1921A36024C92A705BDA0DD87223C.description: Knowledge related to themes of religious culture: Competency 2 – Demonstrates an understanding of the phenomenon of religion

17400E66788541F88C866C4335F0FB09.description: Makes connections between human ambivalence and the recognition of others

7E77AB277731463494551A4693FE0434.description: Makes connections between human ambivalence and the pursuit of the common good

D3354C5DEAA54601804022B6CDD16910.description: Makes connections between ethical reflection on human ambivalence and ethical reflection on tolerance, the future of humanity or justice

585D8033DCA7482B807FF41D4E09CDA7.description: Names references that support and enrich ethical reflection (e.g. charters, laws, regulations, individuals, media)

B706508E3E594C58912505BE7826E3C8.description: Formulates ethical questions on human ambivalence (e.g. Are young people more or less ambivalent than adults? Why?)

2206FCB157B84654AFD0582F75E8F86D.description: Describes situations that illustrate ambiguity in human actions (e.g. a country that defends human rights infringes on them to serve its own purposes)

C64666B598AA48F4B75C6AD13919C390.description: Describes situations that illustrate human ambivalence in behaviour (e.g. a driver is aware that he is under the influence of alcohol and hesitates between staying at the scene of the accident and leaving)

5690E9E2AC22404E8B3B619396C46282.description: Describes situations that illustrate human ambivalence in judgment (e.g. a student feels torn between the advantages and disadvantages of the school’s dress code and hesitates before voting for or against it)

7B3FB152170A400A8DAD53C22089B835.description: Describes situations that illustrate human ambivalence in feelings (e.g. an offended person is torn between revenge and forgiveness)

57CA6CD4DB9746F981949070DAACB5CF.description: Names elements that can be difficult to balance and become sources of human ambivalence (e.g. reason and passion; morality, immorality and amorality; truth and lies; good and evil; satisfaction and frustration; pride and modesty; regret and contentment)

7F0CADA4D6EB43CB8198B649A39ED0F8.description: Defines terms that can be associated with ambivalence (e.g. ambiguity, coherence, equivocation, conflicting values, duality, morality, amorality, immorality)

AAB4260A854443D88C4F1D356F434A5A.description: Makes connections between justice and the recognition of others

FC75C74067DA427EBB32B31CA72CE242.description: Makes connections between justice and the pursuit of the common good

0E386CF37BEA46D295230FC291B4E99F.description: Makes connections between ethical reflection on justice and ethical reflection on tolerance, the future of humanity or human ambivalence

A57C86F23F46452B86BF56DBDAB5AB35.description: Names references that support and enrich ethical reflection on justice (e.g. charters, laws, regulations, individuals, media)

C091288D2BA149DAB579C0E5F4667729.description: Formulates ethical questions about justice (e.g. Does justice mean that everyone should be treated the same way? Why?)

5DFB91B5BF154B0ABDBBD1591495250E.description: Explains, using social or humanitarian questions, or questions about life and death, how justice is seen differently in different societies (e.g. the death penalty exists in certain societies, but not in others; in some countries, it is considered fair for all citizens to have the right to free health care, while elsewhere it is considered fair that everyone pay for their own health care)

BAA945351430417E8A36802FCBC8A737.description: Explains how the way we look at justice influences our answers to social or humanitarian questions, or questions about life and death (e.g. someone who sees justice as retaliation [an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth] would probably agree to the use of the death penalty in a case of premeditated murder; someone who sees justice as a duty to share would probably tend to give to charity)

01774685EFD248EC86CA05D15336A7B1.description: Names principles on which justice is based (e.g. equality, fairness, respect for individuals, merit)

D477C31A6BB244108BABC2EFC7167DF3.description: Gives examples of situations that raise an issue related to justice (e.g. distribution of wealth, euthanasia, working conditions in poor countries)

122B63BC1F0745E78F08571A9B129368.description: Names different ways of looking at justice (e.g. restorative justice, remedial justice, social justice, universal justice)

30F7FCE82C7648AEA577FE15EA9B3DFA.description: Defines some terms that must be understood in reference to justice (e.g. injustice, right, law, fairness, equality, merit, eugenics, euthanasia)

C62CE3465C2D4E53B95FF6DAD8835FDF.description: Makes connections between the future of humanity and the recognition of others

DCA743CCE8334348B665F7580478466D.description: Makes connections between the future of humanity and the pursuit of the common good

A8000E6C7B98403488D3F3894B9C8488.description: Makes connections between ethical reflection on the future of humanity and ethical reflection on tolerance, justice or human ambivalence

94BB86078B2C4EFA80A85AAE6D4155F1.description: Names references that support and enrich ethical reflection on the future of humanity (e.g. charters, laws, regulations, science, individuals, media)

91B281DC273E4C929D52946D7E458399.description: Formulates ethical questions on the future of humanity (e.g. Why should human beings be concerned with the future of humanity?)

98F1B87D847648929429C07C88AE661D.description: Gives examples of how certain references can guide individual or group actions in the face of challenges to the future of humanity (e.g. the value of respect for the environment [reference] inspires certain people to buy local products in order to avoid transportation over long distances)

2CBD954672384E60B0901E0AEA804329.description: Explains some possible actions or options, given the challenges in the relationship between human beings and the environment (e.g. composting or burning organic matter): description of the action, intention, people involved,values, possible consequences, etc.

BFFF9747C4A042D086D954DEBC80E010.description: Explains some current challenges in the relationship between human beings and the environment (e.g. exploitation of natural resources, space exploration, research into genetics and GMOs): issues, actors involved,statistics, scope of the problem tensions, values and norms at stake, etc.

48B267AD22814B558F216636825E48E3.description: Explains some possible actions or options, given the challenges in human relations (e.g. fair trade, economic protectionism): description of the action, intention, people involved,values, possible consequences, etc.

69A995910F784999AB3084C2EA7628EA.description: Explains some current challenges in human relations (e.g. the gap between rich and poor countries, the consequences of overpopulation):. issue, actors involved, statistics, scope of the problem tensions, values and norms at issue, etc,

4A827CC239AA4B768022E73933175790.description: Explains different ways to look at the future of humanity (e.g. Aldous Huxley presents an imaginary vision of the future in a society dominated by science; the reflections of Hubert Reeves and David Suzuki remind us of the importance of protecting the environment to ensure the future of humanity)

1A8EED1BCB9B41C9A71CD3EE9F92EC19.description: Makes connections between tolerance and the recognition of others

9E8AB84E157B42E295CDFDF9E77D4404.description: Makes connections between tolerance and the pursuit of the common good

F9D64B9269A241DB81A312BE7E5C7865.description: Makes connections between ethical reflection on tolerance and ethical reflection on the future of humanity, justice or human ambivalence

4A969EFF693C464D86515682A2D74644.description: Names references that support and enrich ethical reflection on tolerance (e.g. charters, laws, regulations, individuals, media, UNESCO’s Declaration of Principles on Tolerance)

6BD8E8E16E13441B8A350B0846EF6976.description: Formulates ethical questions about tolerance (e.g. What is the difference between complacency and tolerance?)

273161BB8F744A7685F5FBC005391848.description: Explains different individual or collective responses to cases taken from literature or current events that can be sources of tension regarding tolerance: the actions taken, the values involved ,the laws and regulations to be considered, possible consequences, etc

FE308296C72B44A4ACC9C9F235C40ED7.description: Based on cases taken from literature or current affairs, describes examples of tolerance, intolerance or indifference: origin of the situation, people involved, people’s reactions, circumstances, place, issues at stake, etc

C6F6F9CBD65A484FB4CC60F3C75B7100.description: Gives examples of current topics that can be sources of tension regarding tolerance (e.g. same-sex marriage, the integration of handicapped persons, requests from religious groups)

B1956ADE6A4D4FC3A4BEAA5E373CECA2.description: Defines terms that can be associated with tolerance (e.g. intolerance, indifference, discrimination, segregation, racism, xenophobia, reasonable accommodation, diversity)

85572C63B0D7434EAC471C5804488FC6.description: Names references that support and enrich ethical reflection on the social order (e.g. charters, laws, regulations, individuals, media)

0D55752B81C24021930D7DA3526B1F98.description: Formulates ethical questions about the social order (e.g. What behaviour should be encouraged or avoided when faced with a law that is considered unfair?)

F6B18A8C426D45B785F592F5A159F2A0.description: Shows how values can inspire a person or a group to question or uphold the social order and the law (e.g. in the name of justice, a people rises up against the authoritative regime in power; for health reasons, a group of students advocates strict enforcement of the no-smoking legislation)

25C37FA1AF6C408C802EF9C80D5A0B4E.description: Names factors that could bring about a change in social values and norms (e.g. war, immigration, the media, science)

3D520EEF4395448E8C736B0602D2B562.description: Describes different forms of disobedience (e.g. crime [serious, voluntary offence against the law]; civil disobedience [passive resistance and refusal to obey a law that is deemed to be unfair])

DD001ECE0F6743F8924D45FDF36F325C.description: Describes different forms of obedience (e.g. submission [agreeing to submit without protest]; conformity [adopting the same behaviour as the majority])

548CBA2B1348479994B8C593C95A900C.description: Describes different forms of power in groups, institutions or organizations (e.g. authoritative power [imposition of will]; democratic power [taking into account the majority vote by electing representatives])

F5BB4BC1AF6442EA818A55EA877328EC.description: Uses examples to show that the social order is based on the values and norms adopted by groups, institutions and organizations (e.g. in many families, the social order is based on the values of love and sharing, as well as on family rules; in a theatre company, the social order is based on the director’s instructions [norms] as well as on the values of rigour and perseverance)

C724F748E4364BC2B603869336F13265.description: Names references that support and enrich ethical reflection on autonomy (e.g. charters, laws, regulations, individuals, media)

DA4B644180504791A8580DF3CEDF1700.description: Formulates ethical questions about autonomy (e.g. Is it possible to be entirely autonomous? Why or why not?)

081EF30073F64EB79A6710AC747E9A8C.description: Explains how exercising one’s autonomy can become a source of tension (e.g. after deciding to dress in a certain style, an adolescent may come into conflict with his or her parents)

335C7FC3FD0F4E7F99678366EBDC8FB5.description: Shows how friendship, love, academic success, consumption, thrill-seeking, etc., can lead to autonomy or to dependence (e.g. a young person gains self-confidence through friendships with her peers and decides to look for a summer job; a young person enjoys playing music so much that he cannot stop and neglects his responsibilities)

B40EAB1F26A44419B3AB78A590846176.description: Names conditions that foster autonomy (e.g. critical judgment, good sense, moral responsibility, the ability to choose, authenticity, resourcefulness)

20474C3942DD41CD9B5CFA4A8B718F86.description: Gives examples of signs of dependence in individuals or groups (e.g. a person who cannot stop playing online games; modern society cannot function without electricity)

3BD0A19DA50843FB8629B2F0C8A027EE.description: Gives different definitions of the word dependence (e.g. the inability to develop one’s potential without someone else’s help; the state of a person who cannot carry out daily tasks alone)

E3ECF45CABC84897AABDBCAD8D904891.description: Gives examples of signs of autonomy in individuals or groups (e.g. a visually impaired person goes out alone with a guide dog; team members organize their own practice when their coach is absent)

72638CBCFF92433FA4051109B3CFCEF7.description: Gives different definitions of autonomy (e.g. ability to live without anyone’s help; right to self-government)

DF33B1F713D64F48A26E41B186DD2067.description: Names references that support and enrich ethical reflection on freedom (e.g. charters, laws, regulations, individuals, media)

3D2AD856E28D493095EAF77CF3093397.description: Formulates ethical questions about freedom (e.g. How does freedom imply limits?)

2E38C98BB1A34B44836DB1B7B4F43FEA.description: Uses examples to show how responsibilities, rights and duties limit the exercise of freedom (e.g. the freedom to express an opinion in a student newspaper does not relieve the authors of the obligation to avoid damaging another person’s reputation)

1247CBD8EED344D3B509B0B9B25E3A1A.description: Makes connections between the exercise of freedom in private and in public (e.g. one expresses love for one’s sweetheart differently in private and in public; e-mailing a personal photo to a friend does not authorize him/her to publish it on a social network)

1C4C02C7404E443EBEF27D6C568D4CB0.description: Explains what motivates a person’s choices (e.g. a young person gets up early to train because he/she wants to do well in a sport; a group organizes a neighbourhood composting system because it believes that small actions will ensure the future of the planet)

E70BB0A6718442119D34449F3956B3C2.description: Gives the motives behind individual or group choices in the exercise of freedom (e.g. desires, needs, convictions, values, age, education, norms and physical or social constraints)

DED00A3F339E4ACDA53C41ADEF1C283A.description: Describes different types of freedom (e.g. freedom to act [ability to act as one wishes]; freedom of expression [ability to express oneself without fear of reprisal]; freedom of association [ability to join others with a shared objective])

4AE4B40BA0CF46038CFF7D2B32516595.description: Gives different definitions of freedom (e.g. situation of a person who is not dependent on anyone or anything; ability to act without constraints)

056EA41FAC524734BC8C7EB0D72B1B08.description: Knowledge related to ethics themes: Competency 1 - Reflects on ethical questions
